body.p: To the Parnass and members
of the congregation Mikveh Israel
of Philadelphia
Gentlemen

At one of your meetings in the early part
of this year, I asked for permission to be present at the
meeting and to address you personally in relation to and in ex-
planation to of matters which are, as I conceive, of great in-
terest to the congregation on the one side and to me, as your minister,
on the other. For circumstances had occurred, and over which
I had myself not the least control, which had excited feelings
that ought not to exist between us, and I fondly hoped that
a mutual interchange of opinions might tend to enable us
to come to a better understanding, and to proceed in future with
perfect harmony and mutual good will. But a construction of the
by-law, which specifies that none but members & their sons over the
age of thirteen years should be present at any meeting of the congregation,
that the congregation could on no account permit any other than these
persons to be present at their deliberations, deprived me of this pleasure,
and at the same time was the cause, as I truly believe, that the
unimportant difference of opinion between us has not been long
since satisfactorily settled; for I honestly think that a few hours
free & candid conversation would have exhibited things in a light
very different from what some now view it, or at least formerly did view
it. Understanding therefore, that a meeting has been called in
relation to the reengagement or reelection of the Hazan, I take the
liberty of sending you my own views in writing, and I shall endea-
vour to condense as much as possible, not wishing to fatigue
you with listening to a long harangue, or to introduce matters
not relevant to the subject. Let me premise the ardent hope,
that every member of the congregation in proceeding to delibe
rate upon the matter before the meeting will discard every
thing like prejudice and partiality, (and endeavour for
once to throw personal dislike or friendship aside) and vote
in a manner which he can conscientiously hereafter look
upon as the best conducive to the welfare of the congregation
and to the promotion of the spread among us of that heavenly
religion which we have received; and lastly act, not as opponents
or supporters of the present incumbent of the office, but as men
and Israelites anxious for the general welfare of their faith.

To come to a proper understanding of my connection with the congre
gation I will briefly give a short account of my stay in this city, since
it is highly probable that some of the facts may have escaped the recollec
tion of the members. It is now nearly eleven years ago that through
the partiality of several residents of Philadelphia I was applied to to become
a candidate for the office of Hazan then recently vacant through the
death of the Revd. A. I. Keys. I at that time lived with my uncle at Rich-
mond in capacity of a mercantile clerk; I had the confidence of many
persons in the state of Virginia and the city of Richmond, and if I had en-
tered in business for myself my chances of success would have been as
good, to say the least, as that of many young men, who since then that time
have earned an honourable independence and respectable standing.
I had at that time just passed my twenty-second year, my health, though
never very robust, was better than it is now and has been for many years
past; and though young and inexperienced I was not dazzled with the
prospect of obtaining a high & responsible office. On the contrary, I not
only expressed, but truly felt a want of confidence in my abilities to
discharge properly the new duties to be expected from the situation of a minister
properly; and for a long while I absolutely refused to permit my name
to be used. My friends were not satisfied, they urged, that the education
I had received, and the talents which their partiality ascribed to me,
pointed out to me a different calling from that of a merchant; they
appealed to my feelings as an Israelite who ought to labour in the propa
gation of true religion among his brethren; and to my want of a riper years
age which I opposed to my fitness for the office, the averred that
that would correct itself every day, as daily my increase of age would entitle
me to more respect. Without being satisfied that my happiness
would be increased by a change of pursuits, I left, being over-persua-
ded by the arguments of those who were older, wiser and more expe-
rienced than myself, I left the paternal roof of my uncle about
the middle of August 1829 to go away persons entirely strangers to
me, and upon whom I had no farther claims than the community
of faith given to the humblest of Israel's sons upon the most exalted
I had fondly hoped, that if the sufferages of the members would call
me to preside over their worship and to appeal in their behalf
to the throne of Grace, every thing like disunion?, want of confidence,
or the wising up with worldly matters, such as regards salary, emolu-
ments &c would have been banished. But I regret that such was
not the case. In the letter sent to me by the committee of corres-
pondence, consisting I believe of Messrs R. De Cordova, L. M. Goldsmidt and

Isaiah Nathans it was distinctly stated, that the salary attached to the office
was $1000 Dollars, and in fact Messrs Carvalho & Keys both received this
amount, and I hear moreover that it was understood, that the latter gen-
tleman found that amount entirely insufficient for his support. Yet after
I had been here a few days I was waited upon by several gentlemen,
one of whom your respected Treasurer, who represented to me that the funds
of the congregation were then too low to allow the payment of the above
sum. I therefore authorized an election for one year with a voluntary
surrender of two hundred Dollars; but when the report was afterwards
brought to me that I had been elected by a vote of 27 to 7 for two
years at $800 per annum, I also consented though against my original
intention, thus proving that I was not unwilling to make a pecuniary
sacrifice where I thought it was requisite. During the first year, how-
ever, of my residence here, various unpleasant things took place,
which it is needless to call to mind again; and altho' matters were
smoothed over again, still the report reached a distant congregation,
that my situation was not very pleasant here. Therefore overtures
were made to me by several influential members from that place
to take the office of Hazan vacant there. About the same time a meeting
of this congregation was held, at which it was understood that it had been
left to a committee to reengage me at $800 per annum for five years.
As this amount was evidently less than I had a right to expect, I did
not think myself at liberty altogether to decline a proposal made
to me from abroad; yet I made such exorbitant demands as almost
to preclude any idea of their being agreed to; one was an election with-
out being a candidate or going on to be heard beforehand; second, one election
for life; third, an absence of three months every year, and lastly to be
permitted to stay in this congregation three months after the expiration
of my time of service, to enable them to provide a suitable successor.
Strange enough, all but the two first demands (and they in a modified
degree to correspond with the laws of the above Kahal) would have been accep-
ted, if I may put any confidence in the assertions of the heads of the con-
gregation, if in case I had consented to accept office there; but as
their election was to be held in July, and as the meeting of this congre
gation would not take place till September, I declined soon all farther
correspondence, as I could not conscientiously leave this place before I
had made every effort at reconciliation. It will therefore appear,
that whether I could or could not have been elected elsewhere, which
must remain a matter of doubt, I at all events declined leaving

hastily, though I was offered more advantageous terms elsewhere were I asked
here, and it was very doubtful whether your body would recede from their
vote which had been adopted after mature deliberation. If then I put
the congregation in danger of being unprovided with a minister, I put
myself equally in jeopardy of losing a situation, as there was no vacancy
at that precise period in any city in this country, and it is not so easy,
as some may imagine, to change one's occupation, and that at a moment's
warning.

The congregation however found my reasons, addressed to them
correct & cogent, and they so altered their vote as to elect me for
five years at one thousand Dollars. So matters remained for the
whole period, till a reelection became necessary, when although
there was no opposing candidate, still I was only reelected, as I heard
a year afterwards, by a bare majority, despite that there was
no charge of misconduct or incompetence against me. Nay more
than this, after a resolution had been amended to read “for three years
at $1000 per annum,” the resolution as amended was rejected, and
consequently there was properly speaking no minister elected to offici-
ate during the latter part of the holydays, a circumstance which
evidently must be mortifying to one who had for seven years faith-
fully done his duty, and highly prejudicial to the interest of the
congregation, as it was thus in my power, if I had chosen to display
a revengeful feeling, to leave the congregation absolutely unpro-
vided at the very season of the holy festivals. After the holydays
I understand a meeting was held, and an election made for one
year; but by some oversight I was never officially notified of this
fact, and I continued to act under the request made to me by the
Parnass that I might not till a meeting could be held. I com-
menced at that time the publication of the Discourses I had delivered
at the synagogues in this place and New York, which was followed by the
printing of the entire prayer book according to our Minhag. These
labours required a space of about seventeen months for their comple
tion, and I am happy to mention incidently that so far the usefulness of
the one work and the necessity of the other have been amply proved by
the support which as been extended from different parts of this & other
countries. But during their progress another election for Hazan became
necessary, and now for the first time since my first election an active
opposition was exhibited, and votes were openly and privately solicited for a

gentleman who had lately arrived from a foreign country. If any influ
ence was used by my friends to induce any one to vote for me, it was
done without my knowledge, and I may here remark that I
never asked for any man's vote since the first day of my being
called to come here, thinking that in elections, particularly to religious
offices the candidate ought to be removed as far as possible from the
humiliation of receiving a vote as a personal favour which might
otherwise be denied to his merits or qualifications. After a very ani-
mated contest the congregation honoured me for the fourth time with
their suffrage, but now by a decided majority of all the members
of the congregation. But I regret that I am compelled to notice that this
renewed mark of confidence was accompanied by a redirection of
my salary, when I had every right to expect, that you would
have taken the opportunity when voting me in again to increase
my income, as since my first coming here your finances had
so much improved and the member of worshippers so greatly
increased. Why this reduction was made every member knows as
well as I can tell him, and I do not wish to revive unpleasant feelings
by expressing my own sentiments of a proceeding which operated so inju-
riously upon my interests. Enough the congregation thought fit to fix the election
for three years at 800 Dollars per annum; but when a committee consisting
of two members notified me of the result I answered, that I would accept
the office but leave the salary to be farther adjusted at a future meeting.
A special meeting was called for general purposes, but no quorum was pre
sent; of course the committee were not able to report my answer
as their doing so would have answered no purpose whatever. Before
now the regular meeting of the congregation came round, a bond was
offered to me for signature (the first that ever had been drawn up
since my holding office) which stipulated that I would serve three
years at $800 pr annum. As I thought that the reduction
ought not to have been made, and that the congregation at a later
meeting would, as I conceived, see ample reason to amend their
vote, I unhesitatingly refused signing except conditionally for one
year, and the other two to be left for future adjustment. I accordingly
wrote the letter to the Parnass which I believe has been read to you, and
also sent such a bond for his approval, as accorded with my own views.

You will please to bear in mind, that I was engaged in a work of great
magnitude and importance, and which involved an outlay of several
thousand Dollars, which would assuredly have detained me in the
city for a while year, whether I had been in office or not. I stated
this both in words and in writing to the Parnass, but he conceived it
as his duty to refuse the bond I offered, and to insist upon the
one which had been tendered to me. It was in fact, that I should
resign, or sign a bond which I never could conscientiously assent to.
I therefore refused positively for about four weeks. But then reports
were spread, in fact the Parnass told me so himself, that a meeting
would be called, and that my want of confidence in the congregation
would doubtfully so much operate against me, as to prevent any vote
in my favour being obtained. This however had no influence upon
me, believing myself in the right; and there was then the gentleman who,
had been the opposing candidate yet in the city, and consequently my
not serving would have left the congregation the choice of a person who
has since been elevated to the ministry of two respectable congregations.
But appeals were made to my feelings ?, whether I could consent to have
those I had served so long, and that besides that there was enter
tained such a prejudice against the above gentleman by many mem
bers, that they would not vote for him; and thus the congregation would
be placed by my obstinacy, as it was termed, to be without a minister
and that disunion would be the inevitable consequence. Besides this
I ought to trust to the honour and good will of the congregation and
that doubtlessly at the next meeting ample justice would be done to me.
It may have been a weakness in me to recede from my first purpose,
yet if I have erred, I erred for the sake of peace. However this may be,
I referred the whole matter to the judgment of my honoured uncle, whom you
nearly all know and respect, and I told him that I would abide by his
advice. So I did; in a few days I got a letter from him advising me to
accede to the demand made upon my forbearance; I did press my
purpose, I signed the bond, and I believe that no one can say that
either since then or before I did otherwise than faithfully discharge
my duty; not because I had signed a bond, but because I wish to
do what is incumbent on me without faltering or evasion. I had
however good reasons for believing that the congregation would have recon-
sidered their vote, and not regarded the bond in any other light than that
of a peace-offering; but I deceived myself, a bargain it was considered,
and so it has remained to this day. I did not tell you, how galling

such a proceeding has been to my feeling, not for the sake of the amount
involved but because it makes by implication the service in the house of God
one of mere trade, “who shall serve the cheapest.” If I might be allowed
to judge, the congregation ought to choose the most competent, and allow
him a sum commensurate with their ability to give, and not according
to what he might be willing to take. I therefore last autumn wrote
to the congregation stating what I expected of them; and I leave it to
their nonsense of propriety whether my views are right or wrong.

For the future I have to state the following. Experience
has proved that the salary originally promised me is not enough
for a moderate support of a genteel decent appearance. Other
congregations not more numerous or at least not greatly so, and
not having much more extensive means, give their Hazan
a house and from $1200 to 1800 salary per annum, besides perqui
sites which are larger or smaller according to circumstances. More-
over in every instance elections have been made during good
behaviour. We have all learned from observation, that a small minority can
at any election render the result very uncertain, and besides
constant reelections for short periods weakens the attachment of
the minister to the congregation. He knows not whether all his
honest services will render him sufficiently popular to insure
him in his situation and every days longer continuance in office
disqualifies him more for other pursuits if he should have
to resort to them if in case he should be discarded. It is no argument
to say, that such a result is unlikely, as it is within the range
of probability; and the constant harrassing of the mind does not pro-
mote either contentment or good will to others. Some may say, a
minister of religion ought to be above such thoughts, his mind should
seek for heavenly support; it is true that there is some sinfulness
mixed up with all feelings of discontent; still your minister
is a man like yourselves, he has feelings like yourselves, and
if he is injured and his mind is distorted he must necessarily feel
discontent even if he tries to overcome it. The very thing that
he has something to forget and to forgive destroys his usefulness
in part, and greatly militates against his inward peace. This
can be avoided, and it therefore ought to be done. An amiable arrange
ment between us can easily be arrived at, if you only endeavour to

convince yourselves, that the Hazan as an individual has some rights
and consequently some little to say about the disposal of his services, no less
than the congregation have as a body and as much as they are empowered
to select one to serve them, in whom they can place confidence

In consideration of all this I now notify the congregation,
that I am willing to continue in their services if they allow me
the yearly salary of twelve hundred and fifty dollars. This amount
never to be reduced whilst I continue in office. And if the congre
gation are at any time willing to increase this amount, that they never-
theless shall not be empowered to demand any other duties than those
hitherto rendered unless by mutual consent. On this condition I must and do absolutely insist.

With regard to the continuance of office I make the following
proposition: The election to be, if the congregation think proper for an inde-
finite period; I not to be allowed to resign without giving six months
previous notice, and the congregation to be at liberty to discharge me
at any time if an entire a clear majority of all the members either in or
out of meeting shall send a written recognition to that effect either
to the Parnass and board or to myself, as I never wish to hold office
unless it be by the consent of the majority. I know that I subject myself
more to the control of the congregation than by the mode of electing for
a stated period; but still it will then be out of the power of a non-resident
office-seeker to disturb the harmony of the congregation periodically
at the recurrence of every reelection, by not having any incentive or excuse
to offer himself as a candidate, for though I may succeed in being elected
over such an opponent, it is nevertheless highly unpleasant to be under
the necessity of succeeding to the disappointment of another worthy man,
and such alone it is evident will offer himself to your suffrage.
Besides this, if the election stands till annulled by the congregation,
& as it is barely possible that a removal will be made except for good
cause: the incumbent will and must feel himself more at home,
and his mind more disposed to devote himself to his duties, than
under the arrangement hitherto pursued, where he is liable to
be sent adrift with or without reason whenever his stated period
elapsed. According to my view of the case therefore, I can see many
cogent reasons in favour of the proposal I now make to the congregation,
& none of any force against it. For it differs in this from an election
during good behaviour, that in the latter case the incumbent can hardly
be removed except with great difficulty, unless at his own option, and in
accordance with my proposition, whenever the majority changes against him.

If therefore a more worthy man should be within your reach, you can ap-
point him to supercede me, no matter when this opportunity may
offer itself. And my giving six months notice before resignation will
leave you ample time to get a fit successor, as in a late instance in
a neighboring city a new Hazan was elected in thirty days after
the burial of his predecessor.

Another consideration is that up to this period I have been four
times elected, twice when there were opposing candidates; in all I have been
nearly eleven years in your service; of the degree of my fitness all of you have had am-
ple opportunity of judging, and whatever imperfections of character,
qualifications, temper, or behaviour I may be accused of, you have long since
known. No doubt I have given offence very often; but I may freely say,
that knowingly and wilfully I never offended any one. But even if I had
done so, and that you had collectively and individually much to
forgive: still you ought to reflect that during so long a period
many unpleasant occurrences must have fallen to my lot; and if I have
been found wanting in the hour of trial, I can be accused of no
greater fault than any other of my fellow-creatures. At all
wants you know me thoroughly just as I am; and surely it is high
time that I be assured whether Philadelphia is to be my permanent
home or not. I am now past thirty three years old, and I ought to
be no longer harrassed about my future prospects; I am content
with humble means, but I should like to hold them not subject
to the constant caprice or change of dispositions to which all public
assemblies are liable, and none more so than religious corporations.
I will not appeal to your good feelings on account of past services;
as I did have done no more than my duty, although I assumed many more
details than my predecessors did. All I claim merit for is an
honesty of intentions, and a fearlessness in the discharge of my duties,
without regarding my own personal interests. This being the case,
I will leave it to yourselves to determine whether if I am re-
elected, the engagement should not be for an indefinite period,
subject to the limitations specified above.

Other matters, to which I should like to call your attention
I will leave till the regular meeting of the congregation, not wishing
to mix up my own situation with matters not strictly relevant to
the present subject. In conclusion let me again earnestly exhort

you all to judge kindly of my faults, and not to expect perfection from
one so frail as myself. One thing you may believe me, that I have had
a great deal to forgive, and hardly any one can judge of the bitterness
which has often been mingled in my cup since I have lived
among you. It is in your power, gentlemen, to sweeten a little the
course of life of one to whom sorrow is no stranger. If you
resolve to reelect me in accordance with my just wishes, I
shall as formerly endeavour to devote whatever abilities I have
received from the Creator to the faithful discharge of the duties
incident to my station. But if you decline to reelect me, I shall
have the consolation that I have staid among you as long as it
was in my power to do so, and that I did not leave my post whilst
I could hold it with honour to myself and usefulness to others.
I certainly am ambitious; but my ambition will be amply satisfied,
if with a moderate income suitable to my calling, I am permitted,
without fear of a malign influence from abroad or at home to sign
myself, and to be the Hazan of the congregation of Philadelphia.
Yours respectfully
Isaac Leeser.
Not to be opened unless there be a quorum present; if no meeting is held, it is to be returned.
To the Parnass & Members
of the Congregation Mikveh Israel
of
